title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea went missing in 1988 and was unidentified for over 30 years until a DNA test matched him to his aunt in 2025.
Maya Ambrose, a cold-case enthusiast from Newburyport, helped Carolann Angelli navigate obtaining Rea's remains by starting a GoFundMe.
Rea's aunt, Carolann Angelli, plans to bury him with his family, fulfilling her wish to not leave him forgotten.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com released a Greater Boston news quiz featuring Hasbro, Aroldis Chapman, and Matt Damon.
The quiz, including Mrs. Potato Head, tests knowledge on recent trending stories in the area.
Peter Chianca, Boston.com's editor, has utilized AI to assist with the quiz's question formulation.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman may opt out of his Red Sox contract, offering him free agency this offseason.
Sam Kennedy expressed surprise at rumors and stated both Bregman and Red Sox want to continue partnership.
Bregman, batting .279 with 16 home runs in 101 games, plans to focus on season before contract talks.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick supports Tom Brady's 2020 decision to leave the Patriots, citing the team's inability to support him.
Belichick acknowledged financial constraints and poor draft decisions led to the Patriots' decline after Brady's departure.
Tom Brady won a Super Bowl with the Buccaneers in 2020, highlighting his success post-Patriots era.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Ryan, a former town administrator of West Boylston, is suing the town for over $1.3 million after being fired.
Ryan claims his termination was retaliation after he ordered Police Chief Dennis Minnich to remove a Trump flag over ethical concerns.
The lawsuit argues that Ryan's firing was influenced by partisan politics, and the town violated state ethics laws and conflict of interest policies.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old was severely burned attempting a TikTok challenge involving fire and water in North Smithfield, R.I.
The challenge required setting oneself on fire with gasoline before jumping into Slatersville Reservoir, per local fire officials.
The teen was hospitalized with second- and third-degree burns; his 16-year-old companion was unharmed and no charges were filed.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett officials canceled the Fiesta Del Rio festival scheduled for Sept. 20 due to recent ICE raids.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria cited community fear and uncertainty as reasons for the Hispanic Heritage Month event cancellation.
The festival, celebrating Hispanic culture, was to feature music, art, and local vendors at Rivergreen Park.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his Boston mayoral campaign after losing by nearly 50 points to Mayor Michelle Wu in the preliminary election.
Kraft, who has never held public office, was outperformed by over 45,000 votes despite raising more funds than Wu.
Kraft pledges to donate $3 million to address crises in Boston and continues commitment to public service and local issues.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Coach Josh McDaniels defends QB Drake Maye, emphasizing a long-term vision for his development with the Patriots.
Maye faced criticism after Week 1 loss to Raiders, completing 14 of 20 passes but throwing a key interception.
McDaniels insists Maye is not overwhelmed by the playbook and stresses the importance of gaining more NFL snaps.

title: Authorities in a Connecticut town want to speak with whoever is painting the squirrels
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: East Hartford Animal Control reported two squirrels painted red and blue near Naubuc Avenue and High Street.
The squirrels appear unharmed; authorities are consulting with a wildlife rehabilitator on how to assist them.
Authorities request public assistance in identifying individuals responsible; contact 860-291-7572 with information.
